channel.title: I786
channel.description:
[img]http://www.hardware-infos.com/img/startseite/klein/intel_i7_logos_2.jpg[/img]
A month ago or so, Intel released the 7th revision of their processors. These now offer high FSB speeds and brand new Level 3 cache.
What are your thoughts on this new release? Discuss. :)

item.title: I786
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Good ol’ Q6600 still keeps up too.

Read full topic

item.title: I786
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

My AMD Athlon X2 4800+ 2,4ghz still keeps up with the latest games maxed out and it’s fucking 2 years old. New cpu’s are overrated as fuck.

Read full topic

item.title: I786
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

Monkey wacko:

I have the i7 extreme, best and fastest processor i have ever bought, i could be downloading something with Firefox while playing wow and browsing the internet and the processor was running at like 22% CPU usage.

Except WoW isn’t processor intensive, and downloading files doesn’t require any CPU usage at all. Hell, it’s more hard drive intensive than anything… If you bought such a good processor, I suggest using it to it’s potential: hardcore gaming, video rendering, etc.

Read full topic

item.title: I786
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Mopman:

That’s like 90% of the current big software houses then.

item.title: I786
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“T4_, post:18, topic:263431”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=347929.msg2678638#msg2678638 date=1235238994]

If you don’t know how to utilize threads, you probably aren’t much of a developer.

That’s like 90% of the current big software houses then.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: February 21, 2009, 04:57:47 pm[/size][hr][quote author=T4_ link=topic=347929.msg2678610#msg2678610 date=1235237618]
not really anything besides modeling would require that much processing power[/quote]

audio production, video editing, any kind of math intensive stuff that isn’t being done by a cluster already really
[/quote]

Forgot about media production.

it won’t go past 4 cores mainstream, at least not for years.

Right now there is not even that much that utilizes 4 cores, id take more ghz over 4+ cores.

Since AMD own both cpu and gpu, and their phenom II’s are a huge improvement over their older CPU’s and they are becoming more of a competition with intel now, their fusion could be great.

the power of a phenom II fused with something along the lines of a 4870x2 to handle all physics/video rendering, will be the future.

Actually, like all AMD chips, the Phenom II sucks. It is better than the other AMD chips, but isn’t as stable and cool as Intel.[/quote]Pretty sure they are stable. Stock cooling is always a problem with AMD/Ati though, so i always buy a replacement for the cpu/gpu fans when upgrading.

Read full topic

Since AMD own both cpu and gpu, and their phenom II’s are a huge improvement over their older CPU’s and they are becoming more of a competition with intel now, their fusion could be great.

the power of a phenom II fused with something along the lines of a 4870x2 to handle all physics/video rendering, will be the future.[/quote]

item.title: I786
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Mopman:

shit most developers have having trouble coming to terms with the fact that they can process symetrically at all, nevermind desgining apps for 16

If you don’t know how to utilize threads, you probably aren’t much of a developer. The OS should take care of allocating threads to cores. If we can get a 1:2 or even 1:4 ratio of cores to software threads, shit will run fast.

Read full topic

item.title: I786
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:13, topic:263431”]No but it has to be developed in suc ha way that having 16 cores will be advantagous, which barely anything is

shit most developers have having trouble coming to terms with the fact that they can process symetrically at all, nevermind desgining apps for 16[/quote]

Yeah, but I think the gaming industry will take advantage; not really anything besides modeling would require that much processing power. This does raise the question how would you cool this beast - it would generate a lot of WATS of heat. I think water-cooling/phase-changing would be a must.

Read full topic

item.title: I786
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:11, topic:263431”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=347929.msg2678565#msg2678565 date=1235235135]

[quote author=Speljohan link=topic=347929.msg2678235#msg2678235 date=1235218002]

Good processor, but too expensive.

Bring them to the Core 2 * prices and we’ll be right.
[/quote]It’s always expensive during the first release, it will go down within 6 months.

Yeah, I bought my Q6600 for $700 USD back when it first came out; they’re now $275USD or so. These are beastly processors, but I think the wait for the 16-Core chip will be well worth it.
[/quote]Won’t be tho. No apps will support 16 cores in forever. The future is cores adapted to certain things (such as the fusion-type of cpu’s amd are working on)[/quote]

Applications are based off of architecture, not how many cores the processor has. (I am not sure if they’re changing the entire arch. of the new chip.)

And, you may be right - Windows XP probably won’t even boot on the massive chip, but the good ol’ penguin will.

Read full topic
